(Third in a series of four broadcasts on the Italian parliament in relation

This is Graham Hovey, Send ins fro® Home another Letter from Italy, pro*
duced for the Rational Association of Educational Broadcasters with the cooper*
ation of Radiotelovlsione Italians and the United States Information Service.
In my previous Letter X examined some similarities and some differences
between congressional debate in Washington and parliamentary debate in Italy.
But I didn't get around to saying much about the most striking difference of
all.
It is the surface manifestation of that very basic structural difference
between a government of coordinate branches, with checks and balances between
them, and a government that is formed from the parliament and can be put out
of existence by vote of the parliament.
Perhaps I can Illustrate the visible difference In this way*
We all know that a few weeks ago President Elsenhower went up to Capitol
Hill to deliver his annual message to Congress on the state of the union. And
then tho President went back down the hill to his executive offices in the
White House.
He subsequently has sent up to the Hill various messages, asking the
Congress to enact specific adminlstrat .on programs into law and to appropriate
the necessary money to finance those programs. From time to time he may use
the power and prestige of his great office to attempt to persuade the lawmakers
to enact a particular measure -* or perhaps to block one which his administra¬
tion opposes.
But it's entirely possible that the Resident will not return to Capitol
Hill in person for the rest of this legislative session. He would resent
senators and congressmen coming to the White House and trying to run the exe¬
cutive branch for him, and he knows that they are Jealous of the powers of their
coordinate branch and resent too much interference from the executive.
But let's suppose for a moment that the President was an elected member
of the House of Representatives from his native state of Kansas.
And let's suppose that every memoer of the President1a cabinet was either
a congressman or senator.
And now let's suppose that after delivering that message on the State of
the Union in January, the President had to sit there in the well of the House
of Representatives while the House debated his program.
Suppose he had to sit there at a bench located just under speaker Martin's
rostrum, flanked by the members of his Cabinet, andhear himself and hi a program
raked over and over by vigorous and sarcastic and sometimes vitriolic critics.
And let's carry it one atop further?
suppose that after sitting through all this debate, the President and his
cabinet had to remain on that bench during & ro 11call vote of the House which
would determine not only the fate of the program, but actually whether the
Eisenhower administration would stay in office or be thrown out.
